content: The UpgradeReview: Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ Is a Nearly Perfect AndroidA great choice as long as you’re not super concerned about securityLance UlanoffBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 1  “Anniversary” devices are fraught with risk. A company like Samsung, now rolling out its 10th suite of Galaxy S phones, wants to celebrate an important brand without alienating customers who have grown accustomed to certain signatures. An incremental update won’t do, but radical changes could risk alienating the base—and result in a sales flop.With the Android 9-based Samsung Galaxy S10+ ($999) Samsung has, a decade after delivering the first Galaxy handset, effectively threaded that needle, delivering a thin, light, and powerful handset that’s clearly a part of the Galaxy bloodline, while also taking the brand to places it’s never been before.When I raced through key updates on three of Samsung’s new Galaxy S10 models during my brief hands-on a few weeks ago, I was impressed. A fingerprint reader was hidden away under the virtually edge-to-edge screen. The phones could share battery power wirelessly with other Qi-enabled devices, and there were more camera lens options than ever before. On that day, I walked away understanding the essence of the new Galaxy S10 line, if not the individual phones themselves.Now, after spending nearly a week with the 6.4-inch Samsung Galaxy S10+, I appreciate the phone, its gorgeous screen, all those camera lenses—as well as the limits of new biometrics technology. The major question is whether other consumers will.The Galaxy S10+ (as well as the rest of the S10 line) enters a smartphone market struggling to excite consumers who are starting to realize they can get many of the most cutting-edge features—giant displays, multiple cameras, powerful CPUs—for hundreds of dollars less. Samsung and Apple remain highly relevant, but they can’t just spend the next few years saying, “Here’s your new smartphone. Now please hand over $1,000.” That may have informed the announcement of the Galaxy Fold, a nearly $2,000 device with folding screens that launches shortly after the S10 line.Broadly speaking, though, the Galaxy S10+ is a smartphone I thoroughly enjoyed carrying and using. Though it’s fundamentally a gleaming digital slab like many others, the Galaxy S10+ manages to carve away just enough brand identity to feel special, if not unique.DesignAt a glance, the Galaxy S10+ is roughly the same size as Apple’s iPhone XS Max. However, it’s both noticeably thinner and lighter than Apple’s largest smartphone.Like the iPhone, the Galaxy S10+ is wrapped in glass with a rigid metal frame. There’s a prismatic covering beneath the glass back that alternates between pale blue and almost white, depending on how you hold it. And the S10+ offers that signature edge curve that allows the screen to spill slightly over the sides. Though it’s a relatively large device, it feels extremely comfortable to hold, if a bit slippery. The only downside is that the meat of my palm sometimes folds over onto the display, making the multi-touch screen think I’m touching it with two fingers.The new Samsung Galaxy S10+ (center) is very close in size to the iPhone XS Max (at right) and a lot thinner than the Galaxy Note 9The Wide Quad HD+ (2560 × 1440) AMOLED screen is slightly smaller than the iPhone XS Max’s 6.5-inch display, and it doesn’t have a notch. Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ display covers almost the entire face of the device with a laser-cut oval in the upper right-hand corner to accommodate a 10 MP selfie camera and an 8 MP RGB depth sensor.There is a thin black border running around the entire screen. Along the top edge, it accommodates a very thin, but loud, speaker. The black bar at the bottom edge is inexplicably thicker, even though it doesn’t appear to accommodate any extra technology.Still, this is an absolutely gorgeous screen with brilliant colors that hold up well in direct sunlight. Nighttime users will be happy to find that, according to Samsung, the display can cut out 42 percent of the blue light it emanates when needed. It supports HDR10+, and apps, photos, videos, and games all look great. With its Dolby Atmos-backed stereo speaker system, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ is quite the portable entertainment system.Yes, the Galaxy S10 has a 3.5 mm headphone jack, and it does ship with a pair of comfortable, wired AKG headphones.It’s also designed to handle at least some water and dust. Rated IP68, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ can survive under five feet of water for up to 30 minutes. I set the camera timer to 10 seconds and then threw the phone in a sink full of water. It operated just fine—the photo looked pretty good too.Flip the phone over and that overall design elegance is discharged in favor of raw photographic power. There’s a huge 1.5-inch-wide camera array with three lenses: an f1.5–2.4 12 MP wide angle with optical image stabilization (OIS), an f2.4 12 MP 2X telephoto, and a f2.2 16 MP 123-degree ultra-wide lens. Next to that is the LED flash and a heart-rate sensor; while Samsung once relegated the fingerprint sensor to this back area, it’s now nested beneath the screen.Under the skinI applaud Samsung’s decision to place the ultrasonic fingerprint reader under the screen. It’s the kind of hidden-away-until-you-need-it technology you may dream of. Registering your finger on the array, which lives a centimeter up from the bottom edge, works similarly to how it does with optical scanners. The screen guided me through pressing my finger down on the screen as it vibrated and displayed a thumbprint graphic to let me know that it had read a portion of my print. I had to press a lot harder than I ever did with, say, Apple’s Touch ID, but it eventually got my thumbprint. (I could—and did—register multiple digits.)Registering my thumb on the ultrasonic fingerprint readerMy initial tests with unlocking the screen using my registered thumb were not very good. I kept getting messages to press harder and to make sure that my finger covered the sensor completely—tricky business, since I couldn’t see the sensor. Eventually, Samsung sent out a software update intended to improve its prerelease software.It turns out the ultrasonic fingerprint registration system is a little bit more finicky than, say, the ones I’ve found on countless Touch ID-enabled iPhones. The key to making the ultrasonic fingerprint reader work properly is registering your finger at approximately the same angle you’ll be using all the time. So, even though the registration image shows a perfectly vertical fingerprint, I needed to register my digit at a more natural angle. Once I did that, I was able to unlock my phone with my thumb 99 percent of the time.Because the Samsung Galaxy S10+ includes a depth camera on the front, it’s also capable of facial recognition or “Face Unlock.” I registered my mug and often used that convenience feature to unlock my phone.Samsung readily acknowledges that facial recognition is not the most secure biometric option. The company recommends you use a fingerprint, password, or pattern unlock instead. You can’t even access Samsung Pay or your secure folders using your face.To that point, on a whim, I tried unlocking the phone with an image of my face displayed on an iPhone 7. I set the brightness on the iPhone as high as possible and faced the iPhone screen toward my locked Samsung Galaxy S10+. After wiggling the iPhone around a bit, the Galaxy S10+ unlocked. I figured it was a fluke, so I tried it again. Eventually, by moving the image on my iPhone 7 around a bit, I could unlock the Samsung. It wasn’t foolproof, but it happened often enough to be concerning.I would not project these findings out to all facial recognitions systems. Microsoft’s Hello and Apple’s Face ID, for instance, do some sophisticated 3D face mapping to understand the features and contours of your face. I have never been able to spoof Apple’s technology with an image of my own face. I did help fool it with a pair of identical twins, but that’s a special use case.I sent Samsung my test video and, while they wouldn’t comment on it directly, a representative did reiterate the enhanced security level of the ultrasonic fingerprint reader and noted that Face Unlock is primarily for all those people who don’t even bother to put PINs or passcodes on their phones. I would argue those are the same people who store a file called “passwords” on their devices.Picture timeSamsung’s multicamera array and redesigned software results in the best photographic experience I’ve ever had with a Samsung phone. I can now easily find all the camera settings in the simplified app, and each lens, with the assistance of backing software and hardware, produced some truly eye-popping imagery.I even came to appreciate the Samsung Camera app’s somewhat idiosyncratic lens iconography, which uses images of trees to let you switch between standard 12 MP, telephoto, and ultra-wide photos.Samsung’s camera system is backed by a neural processing unit that helps the camera app detect 30 different scenes (people, clothing, faces, babies, vehicles, etc.), and it will adjust color saturation and contrast to fit each subject. The camera app has a little Scene Optimizer icon that changes to reflect the identified subject—leaves for pictures of a plant, for example.In some instances, I really liked the results, but when the optimizer started overenhancing faces (beautifying them a bit too much), and because Samsung’s color saturation has always leaned toward the rich side, I turned the scene optimizer off. When I really wanted to control my photographs, I switched to the camera’s nifty “Pro” settings. I really wish Apple would introduce a similar setting in its camera app.A closer look at the Best Shot interface. To line up the best shot, you line up the two circlesSamsung’s Best Shot feature, which you can enable in the app, is also, for me, a little hit or miss. The idea is that the app can analyze your frame and help capture the perfect (or “best”) shot by having you line up a circle on your screen with another circle outline. Once they’re lined up, and you hold still for a moment, the camera automatically takes the shot. Sometimes this worked well. Other times, the camera app didn’t really know exactly how I like to frame shots, and its Best Shot didn’t match my idea of a best shot.The Samsung Galaxy S10+’s ultra-wide lens can pull in a lot of the sceneThe three lenses are all very good, but the ultra-wide is a wonder. It’s capable of some truly arresting images. I loved getting close to gorgeous architecture and pulling in everything from street level to the top of a spire.Video quality is also excellent. The Samsung Galaxy S10+ can shoot 4k video up to 60 FPS, though the controls for adjusting video resolution are a little bit hidden. It can also record in HDR10+ (via advanced settings), but if you want to play that back on a big screen, you’ll need a TV that also supports that flavor of HDR (a Samsung QLED set should work nicely, of course). As with the Galaxy S9, the S10+ can shoot in 960-frames-per-second, super slow motion, but now it can shoot at that reduced speed for twice as long. A gimmick like this is fun until you realize you have nothing you want to see at that speed.Samsung’s 10 MP front-facing camera and its Live Focus (which works with the front and rear cameras) is improved over the Galaxy S9. Similar to the iPhone XS Max, the Galaxy S10+ can change the depth focus on an image after I take the photo. Unlike the iPhone, I can also make that adjustment during photography. The software that stitches together your sharp foreground subject and the blurred background does an excellent job. One thing Samsung’s software doesn’t do, though, is continue the depth focus through the subject. Apple’s iPhone XS Portrait Mode can, after you’ve taken the photo, reduce the depth of field through the subject. For example, the front of a pet would be in focus, while the tail and hindquarters are blurred. Samsung’s Live Focus still sees the subject and background as two planes.Captured using the Galaxy S10+’s Color Point Artistic Live Focus effectSamsung also included some kitschy Live Focus effects, like a background spin or the appearance that the background is zooming in while you stay put. These are fun for a little bit, but they quickly grow stale. The most effective and artistic is the color point effect, which lets you remove the hue from the background while leaving your subject in brilliant full color.I also used the front-facing camera to build a new AR Emoji, which used a real photo of my face to create my virtual 3D self. The result is something slightly more realistic and a lot less cute than what Apple’s anime-influenced Animoji system provides. I like putting my AR Emoji head over mine and was impressed with how the depth camera helped the AR Emoji track my movements and expressions.It was also fun to use my camera and have my mini AR Emoji appear in the real world. There’s no earth-shattering use case for this, but it is entertaining.BixbyFar from giving up on its digital voice assistant. Samsung continues to polish its smart assistant Bixby, which now does a decent job of responding to my voice and answering general interest questions like “What’s the capital of Arkansas?” It still has its own dedicated button on the device, and it’s also able to access system-level operations, like changing the phone brightness to 50 percent. I was also able to launch Spotify, but once the music was playing through the speakers, Bixby could no longer hear me say, “Hey Bixby, stop the music,” even when I yelled the command.Samsung also added Bixby Routines to help you digitally manage scenarios like taking a drive or going to sleep. Basically, these routines string different functions together depending on use-case—there’s a “save battery at night” function, for example. I didn’t find them very useful, but perhaps Bixby needs more time to improve.To start using Bixby, you train it on your voiceThere’s also Bixby Vision as part of the camera app. It’s good for identifying flowers, food, and translating text.My problem with Bixby is that I prefer to use Google Assistant, which is also part of the Android 9 OS underlying the Samsung smartphone platform. I still don’t understand why I need a second voice assistant on my phone—it’s the same issue with Samsung’s second set of proprietary mail, calendar, and browser apps. I choose Android for the pure Google experience, which continues to my desktop PC.Samsung’s goal, of course, is for you to own a galaxy of Samsung devices—phone, tablet, VR headset, smart home hub, smartwatch—and live in the Samsung ecosystem, much as you would Apple’s iCloud, with Bixby’s intelligence spanning across all these devices and services. I just don’t know that anyone wants to.Performance and batteryVirtually every new Android smartphone coming to market over the next six months will be running on Qualcomm’s new Snapdragon 855 mobile CPU, and though the Galaxy S10+ specs don’t list it as such, Samsung’s new handset is no exception. According to Geekbench, there are eight cores: four of them run at 1.79 GHz, three at 2.42 GHz, and one at 2.84 GHz. The octa-core system is supported by almost 8 GB of RAM (and 128 GB of storage).With Geekbench CPU scores of 3,521 for single-core and 11,075 for multi-core, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ comes within shooting distance of Apple’s A12 Bionic (single-core: 4,803 and multi-core 11,494). The difference was more pronounced on Geekbench’s Compute test, though the scores are not necessarily directly compatible. The iPhone XS Max achieves a 21,482 Metal Score, while the Samsung Galaxy S10+ got a 7,454 Renderscript score.These are just numbers, of course, and with most modern mobile CPUs fast enough, it can be hard to see the difference between Apple and Qualcomm’s mobile CPUs. In reality, the lion’s share of the work done by these chips is happening behind the scenes as they analyze and manipulate images in real time, manage battery life, and make local intelligence like Bixby work.I see the cutout. I know it’s there, but I can’t say it bothered meIn virtually every operation, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ was a champ. I did what I could to push it, loading graphically intensive games like Fortnite, Asphalt 9, and Modern Combat 5. I did a lot of gaming on the phone, which was also an opportunity to see if the screen cutout bothered me. It did not. I barely noticed it and thoroughly enjoyed gaming on the 6.4-inch device.Ultimately, I played so much Fortnite that the Galaxy s10+ intelligent battery management system warned me it was eating a lot of battery power in the background. I followed the system’s guidance and shut down Fortnite when I wasn’t playing it.Samsung stuffed a 4,100 mAh battery inside the Galaxy S10+ and promised 24 hours of battery life if all I did was play video. Playing games, browsing the web, checking email, and running social media apps, I got 18-20 hours, sometimes more. The phone supports fast wireless charging, which means you can recharge on a fast-charge-supporting Qi platform almost as quickly as you would a wired charge. I recharged the S10+ from 42 percent to 100 percent on a Qi Fast Charger in an hour and a half.With so much battery life, the idea of quickly sharing it with your Galaxy Watch or new Galaxy Buds makes perfect sense. Better yet, Wireless PowerShare is a new feature that delivers what’s promised and in the easiest way possible. It’s dead simple to launch the Wireless PowerShare feature (under settings), flip over the Galaxy S10+, put another Qi-enabled phone (yes, even an iPhone) or device on its back, and start sharing the power. Battery sharing automatically stops when the Galaxy S10+ reaches 30 percent or less battery life.A new levelSamsung Galaxy S10+ raises the bar for what an Android phone can be, but it also puts Apple on notice with features like under-the-screen fingerprint reading, notch-free screens, and Wireless PowerShare.The phone is not perfect. I think the ultrasonic fingerprint reader registration experience could be smoother (though once you get that right, it works well). I’m also not happy that Samsung thinks it’s okay to include facial recognition technology that can be so easily spoofed.Since the phone isn’t shipping for a week or so, Samsung may continue to tweak the fingerprint registration software. As for face unlock, which Samsung doesn’t recommend you use for actual security, I think it behooves them to update that software or remove the feature.Even with these issues, there is so much to love about this Android phone. The big screen is beautiful, performance is excellent, battery life is long, the body is a pleasure to hold, and the photographic chops are top-notch for any platform. If I owned a Galaxy 8, I’d upgrade in a heartbeat.
html:

The Upgrade

Review: Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ Is a Nearly Perfect Android

A great choice as long as you’re not super concerned about security

Lance Ulanoff
Mar 1

“Anniversary” devices are fraught with risk. A company like Samsung, now rolling out its 10th suite of Galaxy S phones, wants to celebrate an important brand without alienating customers who have grown accustomed to certain signatures. An incremental update won’t do, but radical changes could risk alienating the base—and result in a sales flop.

With the Android 9-based Samsung Galaxy S10+ ($999) Samsung has, a decade after delivering the first Galaxy handset, effectively threaded that needle, delivering a thin, light, and powerful handset that’s clearly a part of the Galaxy bloodline, while also taking the brand to places it’s never been before.

When I raced through key updates on three of Samsung’s new Galaxy S10 models during my brief hands-on a few weeks ago, I was impressed. A fingerprint reader was hidden away under the virtually edge-to-edge screen. The phones could share battery power wirelessly with other Qi-enabled devices, and there were more camera lens options than ever before. On that day, I walked away understanding the essence of the new Galaxy S10 line, if not the individual phones themselves.

Now, after spending nearly a week with the 6.4-inch Samsung Galaxy S10+, I appreciate the phone, its gorgeous screen, all those camera lenses—as well as the limits of new biometrics technology. The major question is whether other consumers will.

The Galaxy S10+ (as well as the rest of the S10 line) enters a smartphone market struggling to excite consumers who are starting to realize they can get many of the most cutting-edge features—giant displays, multiple cameras, powerful CPUs—for hundreds of dollars less. Samsung and Apple remain highly relevant, but they can’t just spend the next few years saying, “Here’s your new smartphone. Now please hand over $1,000.” That may have informed the announcement of the Galaxy Fold, a nearly $2,000 device with folding screens that launches shortly after the S10 line.

Broadly speaking, though, the Galaxy S10+ is a smartphone I thoroughly enjoyed carrying and using. Though it’s fundamentally a gleaming digital slab like many others, the Galaxy S10+ manages to carve away just enough brand identity to feel special, if not unique.

Design

At a glance, the Galaxy S10+ is roughly the same size as Apple’s iPhone XS Max. However, it’s both noticeably thinner and lighter than Apple’s largest smartphone.

Like the iPhone, the Galaxy S10+ is wrapped in glass with a rigid metal frame. There’s a prismatic covering beneath the glass back that alternates between pale blue and almost white, depending on how you hold it. And the S10+ offers that signature edge curve that allows the screen to spill slightly over the sides. Though it’s a relatively large device, it feels extremely comfortable to hold, if a bit slippery. The only downside is that the meat of my palm sometimes folds over onto the display, making the multi-touch screen think I’m touching it with two fingers.

The Wide Quad HD+ (2560 × 1440) AMOLED screen is slightly smaller than the iPhone XS Max’s 6.5-inch display, and it doesn’t have a notch. Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ display covers almost the entire face of the device with a laser-cut oval in the upper right-hand corner to accommodate a 10 MP selfie camera and an 8 MP RGB depth sensor.

There is a thin black border running around the entire screen. Along the top edge, it accommodates a very thin, but loud, speaker. The black bar at the bottom edge is inexplicably thicker, even though it doesn’t appear to accommodate any extra technology.

Still, this is an absolutely gorgeous screen with brilliant colors that hold up well in direct sunlight. Nighttime users will be happy to find that, according to Samsung, the display can cut out 42 percent of the blue light it emanates when needed. It supports HDR10+, and apps, photos, videos, and games all look great. With its Dolby Atmos-backed stereo speaker system, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ is quite the portable entertainment system.

Yes, the Galaxy S10 has a 3.5 mm headphone jack, and it does ship with a pair of comfortable, wired AKG headphones.

It’s also designed to handle at least some water and dust. Rated IP68, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ can survive under five feet of water for up to 30 minutes. I set the camera timer to 10 seconds and then threw the phone in a sink full of water. It operated just fine—the photo looked pretty good too.

Flip the phone over and that overall design elegance is discharged in favor of raw photographic power. There’s a huge 1.5-inch-wide camera array with three lenses: an f1.5–2.4 12 MP wide angle with optical image stabilization (OIS), an f2.4 12 MP 2X telephoto, and a f2.2 16 MP 123-degree ultra-wide lens. Next to that is the LED flash and a heart-rate sensor; while Samsung once relegated the fingerprint sensor to this back area, it’s now nested beneath the screen.

Under the skin

I applaud Samsung’s decision to place the ultrasonic fingerprint reader under the screen. It’s the kind of hidden-away-until-you-need-it technology you may dream of. Registering your finger on the array, which lives a centimeter up from the bottom edge, works similarly to how it does with optical scanners. The screen guided me through pressing my finger down on the screen as it vibrated and displayed a thumbprint graphic to let me know that it had read a portion of my print. I had to press a lot harder than I ever did with, say, Apple’s Touch ID, but it eventually got my thumbprint. (I could—and did—register multiple digits.)

My initial tests with unlocking the screen using my registered thumb were not very good. I kept getting messages to press harder and to make sure that my finger covered the sensor completely—tricky business, since I couldn’t see the sensor. Eventually, Samsung sent out a software update intended to improve its prerelease software.

It turns out the ultrasonic fingerprint registration system is a little bit more finicky than, say, the ones I’ve found on countless Touch ID-enabled iPhones. The key to making the ultrasonic fingerprint reader work properly is registering your finger at approximately the same angle you’ll be using all the time. So, even though the registration image shows a perfectly vertical fingerprint, I needed to register my digit at a more natural angle. Once I did that, I was able to unlock my phone with my thumb 99 percent of the time.

Because the Samsung Galaxy S10+ includes a depth camera on the front, it’s also capable of facial recognition or “Face Unlock.” I registered my mug and often used that convenience feature to unlock my phone.

Samsung readily acknowledges that facial recognition is not the most secure biometric option. The company recommends you use a fingerprint, password, or pattern unlock instead. You can’t even access Samsung Pay or your secure folders using your face.

To that point, on a whim, I tried unlocking the phone with an image of my face displayed on an iPhone 7. I set the brightness on the iPhone as high as possible and faced the iPhone screen toward my locked Samsung Galaxy S10+. After wiggling the iPhone around a bit, the Galaxy S10+ unlocked. I figured it was a fluke, so I tried it again. Eventually, by moving the image on my iPhone 7 around a bit, I could unlock the Samsung. It wasn’t foolproof, but it happened often enough to be concerning.

I would not project these findings out to all facial recognitions systems. Microsoft’s Hello and Apple’s Face ID, for instance, do some sophisticated 3D face mapping to understand the features and contours of your face. I have never been able to spoof Apple’s technology with an image of my own face. I did help fool it with a pair of identical twins, but that’s a special use case.

I sent Samsung my test video and, while they wouldn’t comment on it directly, a representative did reiterate the enhanced security level of the ultrasonic fingerprint reader and noted that Face Unlock is primarily for all those people who don’t even bother to put PINs or passcodes on their phones. I would argue those are the same people who store a file called “passwords” on their devices.

Picture time

Samsung’s multicamera array and redesigned software results in the best photographic experience I’ve ever had with a Samsung phone. I can now easily find all the camera settings in the simplified app, and each lens, with the assistance of backing software and hardware, produced some truly eye-popping imagery.

I even came to appreciate the Samsung Camera app’s somewhat idiosyncratic lens iconography, which uses images of trees to let you switch between standard 12 MP, telephoto, and ultra-wide photos.

Samsung’s camera system is backed by a neural processing unit that helps the camera app detect 30 different scenes (people, clothing, faces, babies, vehicles, etc.), and it will adjust color saturation and contrast to fit each subject. The camera app has a little Scene Optimizer icon that changes to reflect the identified subject—leaves for pictures of a plant, for example.

In some instances, I really liked the results, but when the optimizer started overenhancing faces (beautifying them a bit too much), and because Samsung’s color saturation has always leaned toward the rich side, I turned the scene optimizer off. When I really wanted to control my photographs, I switched to the camera’s nifty “Pro” settings. I really wish Apple would introduce a similar setting in its camera app.

Samsung’s Best Shot feature, which you can enable in the app, is also, for me, a little hit or miss. The idea is that the app can analyze your frame and help capture the perfect (or “best”) shot by having you line up a circle on your screen with another circle outline. Once they’re lined up, and you hold still for a moment, the camera automatically takes the shot. Sometimes this worked well. Other times, the camera app didn’t really know exactly how I like to frame shots, and its Best Shot didn’t match my idea of a best shot.

The three lenses are all very good, but the ultra-wide is a wonder. It’s capable of some truly arresting images. I loved getting close to gorgeous architecture and pulling in everything from street level to the top of a spire.

Video quality is also excellent. The Samsung Galaxy S10+ can shoot 4k video up to 60 FPS, though the controls for adjusting video resolution are a little bit hidden. It can also record in HDR10+ (via advanced settings), but if you want to play that back on a big screen, you’ll need a TV that also supports that flavor of HDR (a Samsung QLED set should work nicely, of course). As with the Galaxy S9, the S10+ can shoot in 960-frames-per-second, super slow motion, but now it can shoot at that reduced speed for twice as long. A gimmick like this is fun until you realize you have nothing you want to see at that speed.

Samsung’s 10 MP front-facing camera and its Live Focus (which works with the front and rear cameras) is improved over the Galaxy S9. Similar to the iPhone XS Max, the Galaxy S10+ can change the depth focus on an image after I take the photo. Unlike the iPhone, I can also make that adjustment during photography. The software that stitches together your sharp foreground subject and the blurred background does an excellent job. One thing Samsung’s software doesn’t do, though, is continue the depth focus through the subject. Apple’s iPhone XS Portrait Mode can, after you’ve taken the photo, reduce the depth of field through the subject. For example, the front of a pet would be in focus, while the tail and hindquarters are blurred. Samsung’s Live Focus still sees the subject and background as two planes.

Samsung also included some kitschy Live Focus effects, like a background spin or the appearance that the background is zooming in while you stay put. These are fun for a little bit, but they quickly grow stale. The most effective and artistic is the color point effect, which lets you remove the hue from the background while leaving your subject in brilliant full color.

I also used the front-facing camera to build a new AR Emoji, which used a real photo of my face to create my virtual 3D self. The result is something slightly more realistic and a lot less cute than what Apple’s anime-influenced Animoji system provides. I like putting my AR Emoji head over mine and was impressed with how the depth camera helped the AR Emoji track my movements and expressions.

It was also fun to use my camera and have my mini AR Emoji appear in the real world. There’s no earth-shattering use case for this, but it is entertaining.

Bixby

Far from giving up on its digital voice assistant. Samsung continues to polish its smart assistant Bixby, which now does a decent job of responding to my voice and answering general interest questions like “What’s the capital of Arkansas?” It still has its own dedicated button on the device, and it’s also able to access system-level operations, like changing the phone brightness to 50 percent. I was also able to launch Spotify, but once the music was playing through the speakers, Bixby could no longer hear me say, “Hey Bixby, stop the music,” even when I yelled the command.

Samsung also added Bixby Routines to help you digitally manage scenarios like taking a drive or going to sleep. Basically, these routines string different functions together depending on use-case—there’s a “save battery at night” function, for example. I didn’t find them very useful, but perhaps Bixby needs more time to improve.

There’s also Bixby Vision as part of the camera app. It’s good for identifying flowers, food, and translating text.

My problem with Bixby is that I prefer to use Google Assistant, which is also part of the Android 9 OS underlying the Samsung smartphone platform. I still don’t understand why I need a second voice assistant on my phone—it’s the same issue with Samsung’s second set of proprietary mail, calendar, and browser apps. I choose Android for the pure Google experience, which continues to my desktop PC.

Samsung’s goal, of course, is for you to own a galaxy of Samsung devices—phone, tablet, VR headset, smart home hub, smartwatch—and live in the Samsung ecosystem, much as you would Apple’s iCloud, with Bixby’s intelligence spanning across all these devices and services. I just don’t know that anyone wants to.

Performance and battery

Virtually every new Android smartphone coming to market over the next six months will be running on Qualcomm’s new Snapdragon 855 mobile CPU, and though the Galaxy S10+ specs don’t list it as such, Samsung’s new handset is no exception. According to Geekbench, there are eight cores: four of them run at 1.79 GHz, three at 2.42 GHz, and one at 2.84 GHz. The octa-core system is supported by almost 8 GB of RAM (and 128 GB of storage).

With Geekbench CPU scores of 3,521 for single-core and 11,075 for multi-core, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ comes within shooting distance of Apple’s A12 Bionic (single-core: 4,803 and multi-core 11,494). The difference was more pronounced on Geekbench’s Compute test, though the scores are not necessarily directly compatible. The iPhone XS Max achieves a 21,482 Metal Score, while the Samsung Galaxy S10+ got a 7,454 Renderscript score.

These are just numbers, of course, and with most modern mobile CPUs fast enough, it can be hard to see the difference between Apple and Qualcomm’s mobile CPUs. In reality, the lion’s share of the work done by these chips is happening behind the scenes as they analyze and manipulate images in real time, manage battery life, and make local intelligence like Bixby work.

In virtually every operation, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ was a champ. I did what I could to push it, loading graphically intensive games like Fortnite, Asphalt 9, and Modern Combat 5. I did a lot of gaming on the phone, which was also an opportunity to see if the screen cutout bothered me. It did not. I barely noticed it and thoroughly enjoyed gaming on the 6.4-inch device.

Ultimately, I played so much Fortnite that the Galaxy s10+ intelligent battery management system warned me it was eating a lot of battery power in the background. I followed the system’s guidance and shut down Fortnite when I wasn’t playing it.

Samsung stuffed a 4,100 mAh battery inside the Galaxy S10+ and promised 24 hours of battery life if all I did was play video. Playing games, browsing the web, checking email, and running social media apps, I got 18-20 hours, sometimes more. The phone supports fast wireless charging, which means you can recharge on a fast-charge-supporting Qi platform almost as quickly as you would a wired charge. I recharged the S10+ from 42 percent to 100 percent on a Qi Fast Charger in an hour and a half.

With so much battery life, the idea of quickly sharing it with your Galaxy Watch or new Galaxy Buds makes perfect sense. Better yet, Wireless PowerShare is a new feature that delivers what’s promised and in the easiest way possible. It’s dead simple to launch the Wireless PowerShare feature (under settings), flip over the Galaxy S10+, put another Qi-enabled phone (yes, even an iPhone) or device on its back, and start sharing the power. Battery sharing automatically stops when the Galaxy S10+ reaches 30 percent or less battery life.

A new level

Samsung Galaxy S10+ raises the bar for what an Android phone can be, but it also puts Apple on notice with features like under-the-screen fingerprint reading, notch-free screens, and Wireless PowerShare.

The phone is not perfect. I think the ultrasonic fingerprint reader registration experience could be smoother (though once you get that right, it works well). I’m also not happy that Samsung thinks it’s okay to include facial recognition technology that can be so easily spoofed.

Since the phone isn’t shipping for a week or so, Samsung may continue to tweak the fingerprint registration software. As for face unlock, which Samsung doesn’t recommend you use for actual security, I think it behooves them to update that software or remove the feature.

Even with these issues, there is so much to love about this Android phone. The big screen is beautiful, performance is excellent, battery life is long, the body is a pleasure to hold, and the photographic chops are top-notch for any platform. If I owned a Galaxy 8, I’d upgrade in a heartbeat.

  • Samsung
  • Smartphones

    Medium member since Jan 2019

    Tech expert, journalist, social media commentator, amateur cartoonist and robotics fan.

  • OneZero

    Medium’s technology and science publication
title: Review: Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ Is a Nearly Perfect Android
title_html: Review: Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ Is a Nearly Perfect Android
content_html:
The Upgrade

Review: Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ Is a Nearly Perfect Android

A great choice as long as you’re not super concerned about security

Lance Ulanoff
Mar 1

“Anniversary” devices are fraught with risk. A company like Samsung, now rolling out its 10th suite of Galaxy S phones, wants to celebrate an important brand without alienating customers who have grown accustomed to certain signatures. An incremental update won’t do, but radical changes could risk alienating the base—and result in a sales flop.

With the Android 9-based Samsung Galaxy S10+ ($999) Samsung has, a decade after delivering the first Galaxy handset, effectively threaded that needle, delivering a thin, light, and powerful handset that’s clearly a part of the Galaxy bloodline, while also taking the brand to places it’s never been before.

When I raced through key updates on three of Samsung’s new Galaxy S10 models during my brief hands-on a few weeks ago, I was impressed. A fingerprint reader was hidden away under the virtually edge-to-edge screen. The phones could share battery power wirelessly with other Qi-enabled devices, and there were more camera lens options than ever before. On that day, I walked away understanding the essence of the new Galaxy S10 line, if not the individual phones themselves.

Now, after spending nearly a week with the 6.4-inch Samsung Galaxy S10+, I appreciate the phone, its gorgeous screen, all those camera lenses—as well as the limits of new biometrics technology. The major question is whether other consumers will.

The Galaxy S10+ (as well as the rest of the S10 line) enters a smartphone market struggling to excite consumers who are starting to realize they can get many of the most cutting-edge features—giant displays, multiple cameras, powerful CPUs—for hundreds of dollars less. Samsung and Apple remain highly relevant, but they can’t just spend the next few years saying, “Here’s your new smartphone. Now please hand over $1,000.” That may have informed the announcement of the Galaxy Fold, a nearly $2,000 device with folding screens that launches shortly after the S10 line.

Broadly speaking, though, the Galaxy S10+ is a smartphone I thoroughly enjoyed carrying and using. Though it’s fundamentally a gleaming digital slab like many others, the Galaxy S10+ manages to carve away just enough brand identity to feel special, if not unique.

Design

At a glance, the Galaxy S10+ is roughly the same size as Apple’s iPhone XS Max. However, it’s both noticeably thinner and lighter than Apple’s largest smartphone.

Like the iPhone, the Galaxy S10+ is wrapped in glass with a rigid metal frame. There’s a prismatic covering beneath the glass back that alternates between pale blue and almost white, depending on how you hold it. And the S10+ offers that signature edge curve that allows the screen to spill slightly over the sides. Though it’s a relatively large device, it feels extremely comfortable to hold, if a bit slippery. The only downside is that the meat of my palm sometimes folds over onto the display, making the multi-touch screen think I’m touching it with two fingers.

The Wide Quad HD+ (2560 × 1440) AMOLED screen is slightly smaller than the iPhone XS Max’s 6.5-inch display, and it doesn’t have a notch. Samsung’s Galaxy S10+ display covers almost the entire face of the device with a laser-cut oval in the upper right-hand corner to accommodate a 10 MP selfie camera and an 8 MP RGB depth sensor.

There is a thin black border running around the entire screen. Along the top edge, it accommodates a very thin, but loud, speaker. The black bar at the bottom edge is inexplicably thicker, even though it doesn’t appear to accommodate any extra technology.

Still, this is an absolutely gorgeous screen with brilliant colors that hold up well in direct sunlight. Nighttime users will be happy to find that, according to Samsung, the display can cut out 42 percent of the blue light it emanates when needed. It supports HDR10+, and apps, photos, videos, and games all look great. With its Dolby Atmos-backed stereo speaker system, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ is quite the portable entertainment system.

Yes, the Galaxy S10 has a 3.5 mm headphone jack, and it does ship with a pair of comfortable, wired AKG headphones.

It’s also designed to handle at least some water and dust. Rated IP68, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ can survive under five feet of water for up to 30 minutes. I set the camera timer to 10 seconds and then threw the phone in a sink full of water. It operated just fine—the photo looked pretty good too.

Flip the phone over and that overall design elegance is discharged in favor of raw photographic power. There’s a huge 1.5-inch-wide camera array with three lenses: an f1.5–2.4 12 MP wide angle with optical image stabilization (OIS), an f2.4 12 MP 2X telephoto, and a f2.2 16 MP 123-degree ultra-wide lens. Next to that is the LED flash and a heart-rate sensor; while Samsung once relegated the fingerprint sensor to this back area, it’s now nested beneath the screen.

Under the skin

I applaud Samsung’s decision to place the ultrasonic fingerprint reader under the screen. It’s the kind of hidden-away-until-you-need-it technology you may dream of. Registering your finger on the array, which lives a centimeter up from the bottom edge, works similarly to how it does with optical scanners. The screen guided me through pressing my finger down on the screen as it vibrated and displayed a thumbprint graphic to let me know that it had read a portion of my print. I had to press a lot harder than I ever did with, say, Apple’s Touch ID, but it eventually got my thumbprint. (I could—and did—register multiple digits.)

My initial tests with unlocking the screen using my registered thumb were not very good. I kept getting messages to press harder and to make sure that my finger covered the sensor completely—tricky business, since I couldn’t see the sensor. Eventually, Samsung sent out a software update intended to improve its prerelease software.

It turns out the ultrasonic fingerprint registration system is a little bit more finicky than, say, the ones I’ve found on countless Touch ID-enabled iPhones. The key to making the ultrasonic fingerprint reader work properly is registering your finger at approximately the same angle you’ll be using all the time. So, even though the registration image shows a perfectly vertical fingerprint, I needed to register my digit at a more natural angle. Once I did that, I was able to unlock my phone with my thumb 99 percent of the time.

Because the Samsung Galaxy S10+ includes a depth camera on the front, it’s also capable of facial recognition or “Face Unlock.” I registered my mug and often used that convenience feature to unlock my phone.

Samsung readily acknowledges that facial recognition is not the most secure biometric option. The company recommends you use a fingerprint, password, or pattern unlock instead. You can’t even access Samsung Pay or your secure folders using your face.

To that point, on a whim, I tried unlocking the phone with an image of my face displayed on an iPhone 7. I set the brightness on the iPhone as high as possible and faced the iPhone screen toward my locked Samsung Galaxy S10+. After wiggling the iPhone around a bit, the Galaxy S10+ unlocked. I figured it was a fluke, so I tried it again. Eventually, by moving the image on my iPhone 7 around a bit, I could unlock the Samsung. It wasn’t foolproof, but it happened often enough to be concerning.

I would not project these findings out to all facial recognitions systems. Microsoft’s Hello and Apple’s Face ID, for instance, do some sophisticated 3D face mapping to understand the features and contours of your face. I have never been able to spoof Apple’s technology with an image of my own face. I did help fool it with a pair of identical twins, but that’s a special use case.

I sent Samsung my test video and, while they wouldn’t comment on it directly, a representative did reiterate the enhanced security level of the ultrasonic fingerprint reader and noted that Face Unlock is primarily for all those people who don’t even bother to put PINs or passcodes on their phones. I would argue those are the same people who store a file called “passwords” on their devices.

Picture time

Samsung’s multicamera array and redesigned software results in the best photographic experience I’ve ever had with a Samsung phone. I can now easily find all the camera settings in the simplified app, and each lens, with the assistance of backing software and hardware, produced some truly eye-popping imagery.

I even came to appreciate the Samsung Camera app’s somewhat idiosyncratic lens iconography, which uses images of trees to let you switch between standard 12 MP, telephoto, and ultra-wide photos.

Samsung’s camera system is backed by a neural processing unit that helps the camera app detect 30 different scenes (people, clothing, faces, babies, vehicles, etc.), and it will adjust color saturation and contrast to fit each subject. The camera app has a little Scene Optimizer icon that changes to reflect the identified subject—leaves for pictures of a plant, for example.

In some instances, I really liked the results, but when the optimizer started overenhancing faces (beautifying them a bit too much), and because Samsung’s color saturation has always leaned toward the rich side, I turned the scene optimizer off. When I really wanted to control my photographs, I switched to the camera’s nifty “Pro” settings. I really wish Apple would introduce a similar setting in its camera app.

Samsung’s Best Shot feature, which you can enable in the app, is also, for me, a little hit or miss. The idea is that the app can analyze your frame and help capture the perfect (or “best”) shot by having you line up a circle on your screen with another circle outline. Once they’re lined up, and you hold still for a moment, the camera automatically takes the shot. Sometimes this worked well. Other times, the camera app didn’t really know exactly how I like to frame shots, and its Best Shot didn’t match my idea of a best shot.

The three lenses are all very good, but the ultra-wide is a wonder. It’s capable of some truly arresting images. I loved getting close to gorgeous architecture and pulling in everything from street level to the top of a spire.

Video quality is also excellent. The Samsung Galaxy S10+ can shoot 4k video up to 60 FPS, though the controls for adjusting video resolution are a little bit hidden. It can also record in HDR10+ (via advanced settings), but if you want to play that back on a big screen, you’ll need a TV that also supports that flavor of HDR (a Samsung QLED set should work nicely, of course). As with the Galaxy S9, the S10+ can shoot in 960-frames-per-second, super slow motion, but now it can shoot at that reduced speed for twice as long. A gimmick like this is fun until you realize you have nothing you want to see at that speed.

Samsung’s 10 MP front-facing camera and its Live Focus (which works with the front and rear cameras) is improved over the Galaxy S9. Similar to the iPhone XS Max, the Galaxy S10+ can change the depth focus on an image after I take the photo. Unlike the iPhone, I can also make that adjustment during photography. The software that stitches together your sharp foreground subject and the blurred background does an excellent job. One thing Samsung’s software doesn’t do, though, is continue the depth focus through the subject. Apple’s iPhone XS Portrait Mode can, after you’ve taken the photo, reduce the depth of field through the subject. For example, the front of a pet would be in focus, while the tail and hindquarters are blurred. Samsung’s Live Focus still sees the subject and background as two planes.

Samsung also included some kitschy Live Focus effects, like a background spin or the appearance that the background is zooming in while you stay put. These are fun for a little bit, but they quickly grow stale. The most effective and artistic is the color point effect, which lets you remove the hue from the background while leaving your subject in brilliant full color.

I also used the front-facing camera to build a new AR Emoji, which used a real photo of my face to create my virtual 3D self. The result is something slightly more realistic and a lot less cute than what Apple’s anime-influenced Animoji system provides. I like putting my AR Emoji head over mine and was impressed with how the depth camera helped the AR Emoji track my movements and expressions.

It was also fun to use my camera and have my mini AR Emoji appear in the real world. There’s no earth-shattering use case for this, but it is entertaining.

Bixby

Far from giving up on its digital voice assistant. Samsung continues to polish its smart assistant Bixby, which now does a decent job of responding to my voice and answering general interest questions like “What’s the capital of Arkansas?” It still has its own dedicated button on the device, and it’s also able to access system-level operations, like changing the phone brightness to 50 percent. I was also able to launch Spotify, but once the music was playing through the speakers, Bixby could no longer hear me say, “Hey Bixby, stop the music,” even when I yelled the command.

Samsung also added Bixby Routines to help you digitally manage scenarios like taking a drive or going to sleep. Basically, these routines string different functions together depending on use-case—there’s a “save battery at night” function, for example. I didn’t find them very useful, but perhaps Bixby needs more time to improve.

There’s also Bixby Vision as part of the camera app. It’s good for identifying flowers, food, and translating text.

My problem with Bixby is that I prefer to use Google Assistant, which is also part of the Android 9 OS underlying the Samsung smartphone platform. I still don’t understand why I need a second voice assistant on my phone—it’s the same issue with Samsung’s second set of proprietary mail, calendar, and browser apps. I choose Android for the pure Google experience, which continues to my desktop PC.

Samsung’s goal, of course, is for you to own a galaxy of Samsung devices—phone, tablet, VR headset, smart home hub, smartwatch—and live in the Samsung ecosystem, much as you would Apple’s iCloud, with Bixby’s intelligence spanning across all these devices and services. I just don’t know that anyone wants to.

Performance and battery

Virtually every new Android smartphone coming to market over the next six months will be running on Qualcomm’s new Snapdragon 855 mobile CPU, and though the Galaxy S10+ specs don’t list it as such, Samsung’s new handset is no exception. According to Geekbench, there are eight cores: four of them run at 1.79 GHz, three at 2.42 GHz, and one at 2.84 GHz. The octa-core system is supported by almost 8 GB of RAM (and 128 GB of storage).

With Geekbench CPU scores of 3,521 for single-core and 11,075 for multi-core, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ comes within shooting distance of Apple’s A12 Bionic (single-core: 4,803 and multi-core 11,494). The difference was more pronounced on Geekbench’s Compute test, though the scores are not necessarily directly compatible. The iPhone XS Max achieves a 21,482 Metal Score, while the Samsung Galaxy S10+ got a 7,454 Renderscript score.

These are just numbers, of course, and with most modern mobile CPUs fast enough, it can be hard to see the difference between Apple and Qualcomm’s mobile CPUs. In reality, the lion’s share of the work done by these chips is happening behind the scenes as they analyze and manipulate images in real time, manage battery life, and make local intelligence like Bixby work.

In virtually every operation, the Samsung Galaxy S10+ was a champ. I did what I could to push it, loading graphically intensive games like Fortnite, Asphalt 9, and Modern Combat 5. I did a lot of gaming on the phone, which was also an opportunity to see if the screen cutout bothered me. It did not. I barely noticed it and thoroughly enjoyed gaming on the 6.4-inch device.

Ultimately, I played so much Fortnite that the Galaxy s10+ intelligent battery management system warned me it was eating a lot of battery power in the background. I followed the system’s guidance and shut down Fortnite when I wasn’t playing it.

Samsung stuffed a 4,100 mAh battery inside the Galaxy S10+ and promised 24 hours of battery life if all I did was play video. Playing games, browsing the web, checking email, and running social media apps, I got 18-20 hours, sometimes more. The phone supports fast wireless charging, which means you can recharge on a fast-charge-supporting Qi platform almost as quickly as you would a wired charge. I recharged the S10+ from 42 percent to 100 percent on a Qi Fast Charger in an hour and a half.

With so much battery life, the idea of quickly sharing it with your Galaxy Watch or new Galaxy Buds makes perfect sense. Better yet, Wireless PowerShare is a new feature that delivers what’s promised and in the easiest way possible. It’s dead simple to launch the Wireless PowerShare feature (under settings), flip over the Galaxy S10+, put another Qi-enabled phone (yes, even an iPhone) or device on its back, and start sharing the power. Battery sharing automatically stops when the Galaxy S10+ reaches 30 percent or less battery life.

A new level

Samsung Galaxy S10+ raises the bar for what an Android phone can be, but it also puts Apple on notice with features like under-the-screen fingerprint reading, notch-free screens, and Wireless PowerShare.

The phone is not perfect. I think the ultrasonic fingerprint reader registration experience could be smoother (though once you get that right, it works well). I’m also not happy that Samsung thinks it’s okay to include facial recognition technology that can be so easily spoofed.

Since the phone isn’t shipping for a week or so, Samsung may continue to tweak the fingerprint registration software. As for face unlock, which Samsung doesn’t recommend you use for actual security, I think it behooves them to update that software or remove the feature.

Even with these issues, there is so much to love about this Android phone. The big screen is beautiful, performance is excellent, battery life is long, the body is a pleasure to hold, and the photographic chops are top-notch for any platform. If I owned a Galaxy 8, I’d upgrade in a heartbeat.
